attr.q: Explain why \sqrt{xy} \leq (x+y)/2 for any two positive real numbers x and y. (The geometric mean is always less than the arithmetic mean.)
attr.a: \begin {aligned} & 0 \leq (x-y)^2 \\ & \rightarrow 0 \leq x^2 - 2xy + y^2 \\ & \rightarrow 4xy \leq x^2 + 2xy + y^2\\ & \rightarrow 4xy \leq (x+y)^2 \\ & \rightarrow 2\sqrt{xy} \leq x+y \\ & \rightarrow \sqrt{xy} \leq \frac {x+y} {2} \end {aligned}

attr.q:
Now let 0 \leq x_1 \leq y_1 and define

x_{n+1} = \sqrt{x_n y_n} \quad \text{and} \quad y_{n+1} = \frac {x_n + y_n} 2

Show \lim x_n and \lim y_n both exist and are equal.
attr.a:
(x) is increasing and it can be prooven by induction.

The induction step is that if x_n < y_n then x_{n+1} < x_{n+2} because

\begin {aligned} & x_{n+2} \\ & = \sqrt{x_{n+1} y_{n+1}} \\ & = \sqrt{\sqrt{x_n y_n} \frac {x_n + y_n} 2} \end {aligned}

Since it's prooven that arithmetic mean is bigger than geometric mean,

\sqrt{x_n y_n} < \sqrt{\sqrt{x_n y_n} \frac {x_n + y_n} 2} \rightarrow x_{n+1} < x_{n+2}

(y) is decreasing and it can be prooven in similar fashion.

x_n and y_n are each other's lower and higher bound therefore both sequence converges.

At the limit, \sqrt{\lim x_n \lim y_n} = \lim x_n must be true therefore \lim x_n = \lim y_n.
